title: Ticket #6726: Make interactive submission more first-class
description:
For a variety of reasons, some forward-thinking, the user experience for interactive jobs needs improvement:

1) Submit files from interactive jobs should be able to be submitted for non-interactive batch jobs, without modification.

Currently, the "executable" line is ignored and an error given if it's included in a submit file submitted with "condor_submit -i".

Improvement: HTCondor should accept jobs submitted this way, and transfer the executable (as for a non-interactive job), but not run the executable. Could: give the user a warning statement that the executable will be transferred, but not executed

2) A better, less error-looking message should be given to the user if the job environment is not ready.

Roughly monthly CHTC RCFs encounter a user who thinks they've done something wrong. E.g:

--- The last error occurs sometimes when I submit a job. My request is rejected but I am still assigned to some cluster. Following is an error message:

[szhao64@submit-3 ~]$ condor_submit -i debug.sub Submitting job(s). 1 job(s) submitted to cluster 121316375. Waiting for job to start... slot1_12@e185.chtc.wisc.edu: Rejecting request, because the job execution environment is not yet ready. Welcome to slot1_12@e185.chtc.wisc.edu!

Can you help me fix these problems? Do I need to add some options in the command line? ---

Improvement: make the "Rejecting request..." message more informative and less scary. Maybe something like "Preparing job environment."

3) Interactive jobs in the queue are hard to identify and decode.

Currently, interactive jobs (a) list "sleep" as the executable in the condor_q output, and (b) may go on hold and stay on hold if the interactive job overuses resources (or other hold reason). There should be a more informative error message in these cases and the job should probably be removed from the queue rather than going on hold.

Improvement: (1) replace "sleep" with "(interactive job)" in the condor_q output (2) remove interactive jobs from the queue if held, and perhaps give hold reason as an error message when the SSH is terminated.
